item.title: Microsoft to turn some Hisense Smart TVs into an Xbox
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

January 6, 2026

2 Min Read

Microsoft will expand the Xbox Cloud ecosystem in the coming months by bringing the Xbox app to select Hisense and V homeOS-powered Smart TVs.

The company remains intent on convincing consumers that a myriad of electronic devices—including from Smart TVs, VR headsets, handhelds, and smartphones—can be turned into an Xbox by leveraging cloud technology and Xbox Game Pass. 

Microsoft rolled out a new 'This is an Xbox' marketing campaign in 2024 to underline that point, and has again reiterated that the future of Xbox will not revolve solely around console hardware. 

"As we step into the new year, many of us are looking for fresh ways to play, connect, and explore. That's why we're excited to announce a new partnership with V (formerly VIDAA) that expands where your gaming adventures can happen: the Xbox app is coming to select Hisense and V homeOS-powered Smart TVs in 2026," read a post on the Xbox website.

"This partnership is all about giving you more freedom and flexibility to play how you want. Xbox Game Pass subscribers—including Ultimate, Premium, and Essential subscribers—will be able to stream hundreds of games, from new releases to fan favorites, directly through the Xbox app on supported TVs via Xbox Cloud Gaming."

Xbox Cloud Gaming is currently available on select Smart TVs from Samsung and LG. A number of Amazon Fire TV devices are also supported. 

Related:VR studio Cloudhead Games cuts 70 percent of workforce

Microsoft has bolstered the Xbox ecosystem in recent years with the launch of an Xbox-branded handheld device (built in collaboration with Asus) and ever-expanding support for Xbox Cloud Gaming.

Notably, the company has also released a range of Xbox Game Studios titles on PlayStation and Nintendo hardware—with Microsoft even noting that it became the top publisher on PlayStation for a period last year. 

Microsoft has made its multi-platform push amid declining Xbox hardware revenue and widespread layoffs within Xbox Game Studios.

item.title: VR studio Cloudhead Games cuts 70 percent of workforce
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

January 6, 2026

1 Min Read

Pistol Whip developer Cloudhead Games will make 70 percent of its workforce redundant on January 7, 2026. 

Studio CEO Denny Unger shared the news on Bluesky and said the company has been forced to reckon with "industry forces beyond our control." 

The VR studio was founded in 2013 and has worked on projects such as The Gallery, Pistol Whip, and Aperture Hand Lab—the latter of which was developed in collaboration with Valve. 

Unger said the company has done its best to "pad the landing" for those being laid off and has implored studios with vacancies to consider hiring them.

"The general downturn of the gaming industry, VR's still nascent challenges, including a lack of platform funding, have placed us in an impossible position. And while we've done all we can do to reinvest in our people and VR's future from prior successes, we can't build 'bigger swings' alone," wrote Unger.

"Cloudhead has weathered many storms in our 14 years in virtual reality. Our belief remains in the power of VR as a medium, as a shared dream machine the will one day transform humanity. We have no doubt VR's mainstream relevance is predestined, with future devices that do 'everything,' but it will take studios like ours to be there when the time comes."

Unger confirmed 30 percent of the Cloudhead team will remain following the cuts.
